title: $23 billion tax break could be overhauled in matter of months
text:
Speculation is building one of Australia's most controversial tax breaks will be overhauled as the centrepiece of this year's federal budget , with senior government ministers refusing to categorically rule out changes despite days of reports.

Under Prime Minister Anthony Albanese , Labor has previously baulked at tinkering with the capital gains (CGT) discount following the party's particularly ill-fated attempt at the 2019 election.

But with young Australians becoming increasingly priced out of the property market , the budget desperately needing a way out of its structural deficit, and Treasurer Jim Chalmers speaking of the need to address the country's widening intergenerational divide, some signs are pointing towards a possible overhaul in the coming months.

The government's most senior ministers haven't ruled out changes to one of the naton's most contentious tax breaks. (Nine)

Why is the capital gains tax discount up for discussion?

Readers would be forgiven for thinking all of this is old news – the capital gains tax discount seems to become a major political flashpoint every couple of years.

It was only in late 2024 that reports emerged of the government directing Treasury to investigate a potential overhaul of the tax break .

This time, there are a couple of fresh factors at play.

The first is a Greens-led Senate inquiry into the tax, which has received dozens of submissions and is due to report next month.

The second – and more significant – are reports, published first by the Australian Financial Review , that the government is considering changes to the CGT discount.

That, in turn, followed ALP national secretary Paul Erickson, the mastermind of Labor's last two election victories, hinting this year's budget on May 12 will include some significant, ambitious reform.

"You will see some pretty substantial contributions over the coming months from the PM and from the treasurer, and the lead-up to the budget that will set that out," he told the AFR over the weekend .

Senior Labor figures have since had the opportunity to categorically rule out the changes, but declined.

Anthony Albanese and Jim Chalmers are weighing up some "pretty substantial" policies this year, according to a key Labor powerbroker. (Alex Ellinghausen/SMH)

Take a look at what Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said in October 2024, when he was asked to rule out changing the discount:

"I just did. And not only have I done that, the prime minister has made that clear."

Compare that to yesterday morning, when Marles was asked about capital gains once again but wasn't quite as demonstrative:

"Our position in respect of housing policy is clear. And that hasn't changed. And nor has our position in respect of the tax arrangements around housing.

"And we've got to have more houses in this country and that is a real challenge."

READ MORE: The phone call that will have the world on notice ﻿

Richard Marles said the government's housing agenda "hasn't changed", but didn't categorically rule out changes to capital gains. (Dominic Lorrimer)

Why is the capital gains tax discount so controversial?

Alongside negative gearing, the CGT discount provides property investors with generous tax incentives at the same time as housing has become unaffordable for many, particularly young, Australians.

Introduced in 1999 by the Howard government, the policy allows investors to sell an asset they've owned for at least a year and to only be taxed on half of the profit.

While it applies to all types of assets, it has coincided with a significant increase in property prices:

READ MORE: How much more you could be paying on your mortgage after cash rate hike ﻿

Unsurprisingly, the policy is popular with many Australians who have benefited from it over the past three decades, and a proposal to wind back the provisions has been widely cited as a reason why Labor lost the 2019 federal election.

But, at the same time as the concession is costing the nation's coffers around $23 billion a year – a number that will only rise – the government desperately needs to find new revenue for the federal budget, which is forecast to be stuck in the red for the foreseeable future.

Parliamentary Budget Office modelling commissioned in early 2024 by independent senators Jacqui Lambie examined five options for winding back both negative gearing and the CGT tax discount for property, all of which included so-called "grandfathering" provisions﻿ – that is, exemptions for existing property investors from the changes.﻿

The analysis found reducing the concessions could save the federal budget between $15.6 and $59.9 billion over the next 10 years, while also making housing more affordable.

Leading economists including former Treasury secretary Ken Henry, Saul Eslake and Richard Holden have also thrown their support behind various changes to the CGT tax discount.

House prices have skyrocketed since the introduction of the CGT discount in 1999. (Joe Armao)

Would any changes get through parliament?

One factor in the government's favour is that, if it does decide to go ahead with winding back the tax discount for investment properties, the overhaul would likely sail through parliament.

Labor easily has the numbers to get any bill through the lower house, and only needs the support of the Greens – who have long supported scrapping tax concessions for property investors – to get laws past the Senate, where the likes of Pocock and Lambie are also likely to lend their support.

"There's a real opportunity here for sensible reform to the capital gains tax discount on investment properties to incentivise the new housing supply our country so desperately need," Pocock said earlier this week.

"It won't solve housing affordability on its own but it will help."

title: Angelic face of Italian PM wiped from controversial church fresco
text:
Now you see her, now you don't.

The face of Italian prime minister Giorgia Meloni that was painted on a cherub in a church in Rome has been removed following outrage and an investigation by the country's cultural ministry.

Meloni's likeness appeared on the body of an angel following restoration works at the Chapel of the Holy Souls of Purgatory in the Basilica of St. Lawrence in Lucina, in central Rome.

The fresco that looked like Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has now been covered. (Remo Casilli/Reuters via CNN Newsource)

Although completed late last year, the issue came to light at the weekend when before and after photos posted on social media showed that the original angel's face had been replaced with an image that looked like the prime minister.

At first the volunteer restorer, Bruno Valentinetti, denied the claims, saying that he'd copied the original images from drawings.

But on Wednesday, he told La Repubblica newspaper that it was indeed the prime minister. However, he insisted that it was similar to the original artwork, the paper reported.

Valentinetti was tasked with smudging out his work, which has left a ghost-like white blob on the angel's body.

Italy's Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni pictured on January 9. (Vincenzo Livieri/Reuters via CNN Newsource)

The fresco at the Basilica of St. Lawrence in Lucina that drew criticism. (Vincenzo Livieri/Reuters via CNN Newsource)

"I covered it up because the Vatican told me to," he told La Repubblica .

The Vatican has not weighed in publicly on the controversy.

The culture ministry, which ordered an investigation earlier this week, put out a statement on Wednesday about the removal of the image, saying that works in churches in Rome had to be pre-approved with drawings for proposed changes.

"In light of the removal of the face from the decoration in the chapel of the crucifix of San Lorenzo in Lucina, in agreement with the Minister of Culture, Alessandro Giuli, the Special Superintendent of Rome, Daniela Porro, has informed the rector of the Basilica that any restoration work requires a request for authorisation from the Ministry of the Interior's Fund for Places of Worship, which owns the property, the Vicariate, and the Special Superintendency of Rome, attaching a sketch of the image," the ministry wrote in a statement posted on its website.

Hundreds of visitors have visited the chapel in recent days to take photos of the image, the parish priest Father Daniele Micheletti said. (Remo Casilli/Reuters via CNN Newsource)

Hundreds of visitors have visited the chapel in recent days to take photos of the image, the parish priest Father Daniele Micheletti said.

"I've always said that if it had created divisions, I would have had it removed," he told Sky Italia .

"From a regulatory standpoint, the painting could have remained there for a hundred years, but it has created too many divisions in the church."

title: Vasectomies in Australia spike by more than 60 per cent as cost of living bites
text:
E﻿xclusive: Vasectomies are booming in Australia and many experts believe the rising cost of living could be a factor in younger men going under the knife.

A new study from Adelaide University researchers has revealed the number of vasectomies performed on men aged 18-44 each year has spiked by more than 60 per cent.

About ﻿18,500 vasectomies were performed on men in that age range back in 2016.

The number of men undergoing vasectomies in Australia has risen sharply in the last decade. (Getty)

In 2024, the number had surged to more than ﻿29,800.

Researchers also found the ﻿average number of vasectomies performed per month has increased by about 45 per cent, though the figure was much higher in some states.

For example, in NSW about 25 vasectomies were performed on men aged 18 to 44 per 100,000 male population per month in April 2016.﻿

In December 2024, that figure had jumped to 39 – an increase of 56 per cent.

In Tasmania, the number of ﻿vasectomies were performed on men aged 18 to 44 per 100,000 male population per month rose from 41 in 2016 to 66 in 2024.

That's an increase of 61 per cent.﻿

Dr Jack Janetzki, lecturer in Pharmacy and Pharmacology at Adelaide University and co-author of the study, suspects the cost-of-living crisis played a role in the spike in vasectomy rates across the country.

"Rising housing costs, cost-of-living pressures and delayed partnership formation could all be associated with decisions to limit or forgo childbearing," he told nine.com.au.

"Vasectomy provides a definitive solution to limiting family size amid these pressures and people may now be making concrete decisions on family size at a greater rate."

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

Increasing awareness and normalisation of vasectomy as a safe, effective and relatively simple form of contraception may be another factor.

There's also greater ﻿visibility of male reproductive responsibility now than there was 10 years ago, prompting some men to take on more contraceptive responsibility.

Not to mention that vasectomy is much less invasive ﻿than permanent methods of female contraception like tubal ligation.

The rise in vasectomy rates across the country coincides with a steady decline in Australia's birth rate.

The nation's total fertility rate (TFR)﻿ dipped to a record-breaking low of 1.48 in 2024 and is predicted to slip even lower to 1.42 this year, according to The Centre for Population.

"Vasectomy alone cannot explain Australia's falling birth rate but it likely acts as both a marker and mechanism of fertility decline," Janetzki said.

Data shows a marked rise in vasectomies in younger men, particularly those aged 18 to 24.

Meanwhile, the number of young women aged 18 to 24 ﻿giving birth is declining.

This suggests young Australians are making decisions to limit fertility and are increasingly open to permanent contraception at younger ages ﻿.

"Our findings likely reflect the changing intentions around family size and permanence of reproductive decisions, reinforcing trends towards delayed child bearing, fewer children overall or not choosing to have children at all," Janetzki said.

title: How often should you clean your microwave?
text:
When was the last time you cleaned your microwave?

If you close the door, a little bit of food splatter or a slight smell is pretty easy to ignore.

But according to experts, the sooner you deal with the problem the better. Cleaning the microwave is also a lot simpler than some other appliances (namely, the dreaded oven).

How often should you clean your microwave?

Well, it all depends on how often you use it, according to consumer group Choice.

Choice suggests immediately removing any spills with a damp cloth.

You can also wipe the microwave interior down with a microfibre cloth immediately after cooking steamy foods (such as vegetables and rice) because it will be warm and damp, Choice says.

Sign up to the ABC Lifestyle newsletter Get a mid-week boost and receive easy recipes, wellbeing ideas, and home and garden tips in your inbox every Wednesday. You’ll also receive a monthly newsletter of our best recipes.

Jason Shipway runs a cleaning business and lives in Bunbury, Western Australia, on the traditional lands of the Noongar people.

"We clean houses weekly, fortnightly, monthly and I find the ones that we clean weekly, their microwaves are pretty much never dirty."

Mr Shipway suggests giving your microwave a proper clean about every two weeks "to keep on top of it".

Rozita Vaskoska says it's best to clean up food spills immediately. (Supplied: Rozita Vaskoska)

And if you're worried that skipping a clean is too much of a health hazard, it's probably okay.

"The risks from not cleaning the microwave in general are very low," says Rozita Vaskoska, a microbiologist and senior scientist with the CSIRO.

Recently prepared food coming into contact with old "food remains" could create a "very low" risk of contamination.

But Dr Vaskoska says cleaning up any food spills, splatters or leaks as soon as they happen eliminates that concern.

Other than that, she suggests giving the inside a wipe-down every few days or weekly.

What is the best way to clean the inside of a microwave?

Mr Shipway says the best solution is to use water, lemon slices and vinegar.

"Get a little bowl and fill it with one or two cups of water. Slice up a lemon [and add it to the bowl], add a few dashes of vinegar in there and then you just turn the microwave on high for 3 to 5 minutes."

This method loosens up old food grime and oil stains while also deodorising, Mr Shipway says.

"Everything will just wipe off really easily without potentially harming anything in the microwave."

Choice recommends the same approach:

Adding vinegar or lemon to a heat-proof bowl of water,

to a heat-proof bowl of water, Running the microwave until the water is boiling ,

, Leaving the microwave door closed for 5 minutes for the steam to loosen the residue and;

for the steam to loosen the residue and; Wiping the interior

Choice suggests staying nearby while the microwave is on to make sure the solution doesn't boil over and warns that the bowl will be hot when you remove it.

"You can also remove the turntable [microwave plate], rinse it off and wipe each side down with a paper towel to let your microwave shine once more."

The turntable can also be cleaned in your sink or dishwasher (if it's dishwasher safe and small enough), Choice says.

Choice says it's important to clean up food caught in cracks and crevices. (Adobe Stock)

Choice also recommends wiping the exterior with a cloth and warm soapy water as part of a more thorough clean.

Look for any gunk around dials and crevices (a toothbrush or toothpick may be called for).

You can even make a paste with water and bicarb soda and scrub gently to help tackle stubborn residue, Choice adds.

"Never use anything metal and make sure the microwave is unplugged before you start."

Dr Vaskoska recommends wiping down the inside of the microwave with warm water and a little dishwashing liquid.

"And, then washing the plate as [you would] any other dish would be sufficient."

Methods to avoid

How to spring clean your wardrobe It's the kind of task that can seem overwhelming, but the change of season is the perfect opportunity to review what's in your wardrobe.

Mr Shipway says people often spray a degreaser inside their microwave to loosen up any build-up, but he doesn't recommend it.

"If there's any residue left behind, it's going to [spread] up into the internals of the microwave [when it heats up] and it could damage it."

If you're going to use any products inside the microwave ensure they are food safe, Mr Shipway says.

Choice also advises against using harsh or specialist chemicals for the job.

Dr Vaskoska says "conventional methods" involving detergent, vinegar or baking soda are all good options.

"People should avoid abrasive chemicals or even some flammable chemicals, such as some alcohol."

title: The 70-year-old snub that put Australia on the path to Winter Olympics glory
text:
Australia is heading to the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympic Games with very high expectations.

Since the nation won its first Winter Olympics medal — a bronze at the 1994 Olympics in Lillehammer — Australia has never left a Games without at least one.

There is no doubt Australia is punching well above its weight.

And from that first bronze all the way through to the record-breaking four medals the team won in Beijing, there has been a steady building of success.

But this rise has been hard-fought, with battles by athletes on the snow and ice, and by administrators in boardrooms and backrooms across the world.

And it can all be traced back to a brutal snub by the Australian Olympic Federation the last time the Games were held in Cortina d'Ampezzo 70 years ago, and the fire that ignited in one of those athletes who was denied his place on the ice — Geoff Henke.

'Aggressive' advocacy

"It's an aggressive sport," Henke tells ABC Sport from his home in Melbourne, the 98-year-old talking about the sport he used to play and remained a staunch supporter of his whole life, ice hockey.

"It seems to have bred a lot of aggressive people.

"And I was one of them, I suppose," he adds with a mischievous chuckle that belies his age.

Henke's aggression on the ice can't be corroborated — although anyone who has ever watched ice hockey will have an idea that he's not far wrong — but it's his controlled aggression and advocacy for winter sports that have allowed him to leave his mark on the Australian sporting landscape that few others will ever come close to matching.

Geoff Henke played hockey in Melbourne in the 1950s. 1958 Olympian Ivo Vesely is behind him to the left. (Supplied: Ice Legends Australia)

It's not by accident that Henke's name has become synonymous with winter sports.

Working as chef de mission for the Winter Games from 1976 until 1994, Henke lends his name to two Winter Olympics training centres in Australia, and was pivotal in the establishment of the Olympic Winter Institute of Australia in 1994.

But it may surprise some to learn that he never made it to an Olympics as a competitor — albeit as a result of a disappointing decision made by officials.

"The Australian Ice Hockey Federation wanted to send a team to [the 1956 Winter Olympics in] Cortina," Henke told ABC Sport in November 2025.

"We were lucky at that stage, there were a lot of migrants coming out to Australia, and we had some Canadians and Czechs — they wouldn't make up the full team, but they certainly helped to create a good standard.

"With maybe three or four in the team, which would have been the case, we would have put up a fairly good showing."

Alas, it didn't happen.

"The Australian Olympic Committee were very, very orientated to the Summer Games. And you could see why," Henke explains.

"The then-secretary-general [of the Australian Olympic Committee] Sir Edgar Tanner … he was very much involved with boxing.

"He had the opinion that the Olympic Games, as far as Australia goes, should only enhance three sports: One was swimming, of course, track and field, and his own sport, boxing.

"He was very bigoted and biased towards it all, and, in the end, the committee was influenced by him. He kind of made, really, all the decisions for them.

"So that's what happened. We were all ready to go, designs had been made for uniforms and all the other bits and pieces, we'd been training, some of the members coming from Sydney and so forth, all that was being organised.

"And we didn't go."

How the Cortina snub turned into Australian winter sports' gain

Geoff Henke has helped hundreds of skiers achieve their goals. (Getty Images: Jono Searle)

Henke had the chance to go four years later, but the Cortina snubbing had left a deep scar — scars that were matched by the battering the aged Australian team that was sent.

"I was actually asked [to go to Squaw Valley] but declined, as did a couple of other players," Henke says.

"We just didn't like what was going on. We had our own businesses to enhance, and I withdrew from it.

"The team had three very good Czechs, one was my centre man, Ivo Vesely, but they played against Czechoslovakia. When the Czech players knew they'd be meeting the Australian Czechs, they really hammered our boys.

"Two of our boys finished up in the hospital after that, and another one was injured.

"They didn't win a game and didn't look like winning a game.

"It was a tragedy. Had we gone four years earlier, our standard would have been much higher."

Geoff Henke now has two centres named after him, in Melbourne and Brisbane. (Getty Images: Raoul Wegat)

Despite the indignity meted out on the Australian team, Henke says he still regrets not going.

"I think it was a mistake," he says.

"When I think of it now, I should have taken it. But you feel very strongly about those things.

"Anyway, that's the past."

Henke's Olympic disappointment turned into Australia's long-term Olympic gain, steeling within him a desire to advocate for Australian athletes who would otherwise be ignored.

He was instrumental in establishing Falls Creek as a skiing destination, helping build the first ski lifts in the area in 1961, and, though his involvement in the Falls Creek racing club — where his Olympian daughter Joanne McDougall (nee Henke) trained — was named the Australian Ski Federation's first ever Alpine director in 1972.

Under the patronage of the then-secretary-general of the AOC, Julius Patching, a man Henke said was like a father to him, Henke became the chef de mission and began work on realising a new funding model for winter sports athletes.

"What I was always concerned about was that people didn't really understand what's required to win these medals," Henke said.

So he made them realise.

The Falls Creek trip that sparked a revolution

Laura Peel is one of the many athletes to benefit from the Geoff Henke water ramp in Brisbane. (Supplied: Ben Cocklin)

Henke took the opportunity in 1981 to have an AOC meeting at Falls Creek and allow the members of the committee to see winter sports in action.

Henke recalls that Tom Blue, an Olympic selector and head of the justification committee, "couldn't believe anybody would be silly enough to get out and be involved in sport in a climate like this.

"He was just mystified about this existing."

But despite that mysticism, Henke said he never had anything but support from the AOC members in establishing a funding model for the nation's Winter Olympians.

"I had a great friend in John Coates, who became the [AOC] president, and we were both vice-presidents together — we knew one another very well, and I supported John very strongly to become the AOC president, which he did, and I had tremendous access to him.

"He listened to me all the way, and anything I wanted; there was not one thing that we ever, ever put up that he questioned.

"'Whatever you want, whatever you think, I'm behind you," he would say.

"I give him tremendous credit for that, and you can see the results from that.

"They were so supportive, which was a great change from the old Edgar Tanner days."

Now, Australian athletes are not only competing at the top level, but have the support both at home and abroad to challenge for medals.

A lasting legacy of Henke's involvement in the Games is the water jump facility in Brisbane, an incongruous location for a winter sport training facility no doubt, but one that has paid off dramatically.

The water jump in Brisbane has played host to many athletes from around the world, including world aerials champion Noé Roth. (ABC Sport: Simon Smale)

Henke noted that former aerialist Kirstie Marshall, who he cites as one of the best ever aerial skiers and was denied an Olympic medal only by a knee injury, had to undergo enormous hardship to compete on the world tour.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"The conditions that she had to endure in a nation that couldn't even spell the words aerial skiing or Kirstie Marshall, it's just remarkable how she, how she financed it," he said.

"The Brisbane water jump ramp, that's been remarkable, and look at some of the great skiers we produced there.

"When you think Laura Peel and Jackie Cooper, and of course Kirstie Marshall, Alisa Camplin. Before that one, we had no facilities at all, no financial support … the facilities they had, they were dangerous, really."

Henke was the chef de mission when Australia won its first-ever Winter Olympics medal, a bronze in the men's 4x5,000m short track speed skating relay in Lillehammer in 1994.

Now, 22 years later, the fruits of his labour could be about to be realised tenfold at the same location where his own dreams of Olympic participation were crushed.

And what a fitting reward that will be for Australia's own Mr Winter Olympics.

title: How sport isolated, then helped to heal Bláthnaid following a violent rape
text:
Bláthnaid Raleigh's life was completely changed six years ago when she travelled to Galway for an annual arts festival in Ireland.

While on a night out with friends she ran into a group of people she knew from her home town of Mullingar.

One of those people was Jonathan Moran, who later that night at a house party violently raped her with a bottle in a garden shed.

Five years after the incident, Moran was handed a nine-year prison sentence with one year suspended.

The court heard Raleigh was left with extensive physical injuries that required months of treatment in a sexual assault unit.

The impact of the sexual assault had all-consuming impacts on Raleigh's life. Sport, which had been a constant in her life since she was young, became a point of both further isolation and healing.

'Lost so much of myself'

In the immediate aftermath of the assault, Raleigh found herself sad, angry and feeling extremely isolated. She said even showering became "really, really hard".

"I'd lost so much of myself — anything I kind of enjoyed doing as a young person in their early 20s, like going out and to bars, things like that, I just didn't do," Raleigh told ABC Sport following the release of her new book, Aftermath.

"My attacker was from the same town as me and so going into my local town to get my nails done or my hair done … They were the kind of things I used to love before and I really lost that whole thing."

One of the hardest parts for Raleigh was that between the assault and the conviction, Moran could not be publicly named. For five years, Raleigh had to watch her attacker continue socialising, working and playing rugby in the same town while she awaited the trial.

Bláthnaid Raleigh and her two brothers. (Supplied: Bláthnaid Raleigh)

Raleigh waived her right to anonymity so Moran could be publicly named following the conviction.

The rugby club she grew up in and around, Mullingar Rugby Football Club, suddenly felt like it was being weaponised against her. Moran was a well-known player there.

"My dad, brothers, uncle, all played at our local club … So every Saturday, I was at rugby matches when the boys were playing. My parents, if they were going out, they were going out with people from the rugby club," she said.

"All these memories from my childhood, when I look back, are all linked to the club. And I think that kind of shows how sort of woven into the community the club is."

Bláthnaid Raleigh grew up around Mullingar Rugby Club. (Supplied: Bláthnaid Raleigh)

One of Raleigh's brothers played at Mullingar when the attack happened. As this is where Moran also played, Raleigh's brother left to join a rival club — something that didn't go down well with some in the community, Raleigh said.

"I felt really guilty that my brother had lost his club. His sport was huge to him and he had lost that … It was just really, really hard and there was a lot of guilt and anger — and I suppose there's still anger kind of in me towards that," she said.

Mullingar RFC expelled Moran from the club and issued a public statement to the Irish Times: "Mullingar Rugby Football Club was deeply shocked and saddened to learn on Monday of the crime committed by former member Jonathan Moran. We condemn and are appalled by this act."

Raleigh was disappointed with the response from the club, particularly in a lack of acknowledgement of the pain caused to her and her family.

She said it felt like a message had gone around the club: "Don't say a thing, don't talk about it, don't talk to Bláthnaid."

Bláthnaid Raleigh and her brothers with Aftermath. (Supplied: Bláthnaid Raleigh)

"In those five years leading up to the court case, nobody knew what was going on, and that was fine, and we just kind of put our heads down and got through," she said.

"I used to always say when they know, they're going to be so annoyed that he was still playing or mixing with them, or they're going to think how dare he.

"And then it came out, and it was on national news, national papers. It was everywhere … It got huge attention. And I don't know why, but it just was so evident that there was nothing from the club. There was just radio silence.

"I think one former player messaged and that was it … They had to be asked to take down his photos celebrating him off their social media … I remember thinking, there has definitely been like a committee meeting and they've discussed this and I remember being so hurt that the decision that they sat and discussed was to say nothing … That was so heartbreaking."

The club was contacted by the ABC.

Raleigh said she particularly felt bad no one reached out to her brother to say "we see why you left now" or "so sorry that happened to you and you had to leave".

Loading Instagram content

She also wanted the club as a sporting organisation to make a strong stand for others to see.

She said rugby didn't have a great reputation for sexual violence and referenced the recent "rugby rape trial" - where Paddy Jackson and Stuart Olding were found not guilty of rape in a high-profile case — and "the French rugby story" where in 2024 a French court jailed three rugby players over gang rape that included Irishman Denis Coulson.

"So when you think of sport and gender-based violence in Ireland, rugby is very much linked with it," she said.

"That kind of annoys me about the sport, because I think, OK, you do have a problem. You do need to do something here."

'Getting some control'

Raleigh continued to try and piece her life back together, including wanting to feel better in her body. She tried to take back up running, but found she would often panic.

Then she joined a boxing gym.

"I loved it. I felt like I was getting some control [and] it was really good physically," Raleigh said.

"I would release that anger [and] guilt, but it was also a complete distraction, because boxing is so technical, I didn't have time to think of anything else. So it was like, for that hour, that 45 minutes I was training, I didn't think of anything else."

She said when she started light sparring, it was a huge step because it was letting someone in her personal space. Something she felt she could do because she found the community at the gym such a welcoming and safe space.

"And a lot of the times, a lot of the classes had more men, so I would be sparring against men. So I found it really intimidating at the start. I had to train my brain to think like he's not trying to hurt me, he's not going to hurt me, he's not attacking me," she said.

"Because for the first little while, I used to put my hands up and just kind of take it, and these guys were like, 'Oh my God'. But that release and also that sort of mental thing of, well, I kind of know how to protect myself if I have to, I could throw a punch.

"I felt fit and strong, and it was the first time I had sort of a sense of achievement about me since the attack had happened."

Yet while boxing has helped her in the aftermath of the trial, she said it was her horseriding and showjumping that got her through the five years following the attack.

Bláthnaid Raleigh said horseriding helped her during some of her darkest days. (Supplied: Bláthnaid Raleigh)

She has three horses — Juno, Bravo and Jagger.

"If I hadn't had the horses, I don't know how I sort of would have got through it, because they were my non-negotiable. They had to be fed. So you couldn't let them starve.

"It was the one thing that I had to do when everything else was going so terribly. So now, even this year, I was doing my 2026 goals … and my goals are all surrounding the horses.

"I feel like I'm in the stage where I really want to push on and get more competitive … That's definitely my driving force in life now and in sport — everything I do is for that."

title: Queensland's wild weather brings ideal conditions for barramundi
text:
Commercial barramundi fishers are expecting a bumper catch this year with wet weather in northern Queensland creating ideal conditions for the sought-after seafood.

Ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji brought heavy rain to the east coast just three weeks before the fishery opened this week, while the Gulf of Carpentaria has also experienced weeks of ongoing flooding.

Nathan Rynn is hoping for a big barramundi season. (ABC News: Brooke Tindall)

Nathan Rynn, a commercial fisher from Townsville, said flooding allowed barramundi to move between wetlands and saltwater, making them easier to catch.

"Rain for us is just pure liquid gold," he said.

"It means we can keep the product affordable to the people and we're big believers in that."

Nathan Rynn is one of 27 gillnet fishers in Queensland. (ABC News: Brooke Tindall)

Delays in the Gulf

While ongoing rain in the Gulf of Carpentaria is good news for the $10 million fishery, it has also delayed some of the region's 18 commercial fishers from getting on the water.

Heavy rainfall has now eased in the region, but ongoing flooding is likely to continue for weeks as large volumes of water flow towards the coastal catchments.

Fish retailers are looking forward to having plenty of barramundi to sell. (ABC News: Brooke Tindall)

Gulf fisher Karen Miller, who owns Malanda Seafood, said while the season opened on February 1, many people might not start fishing until March.

"With the roads cut, there won't be many people able to get in," she said.

Ms Miller's partner and Malanda Seafood co-owner Mark Gray said fish stocks would be healthy after the flooding.

"I've been [fishing in the Gulf for] 35 years and the fishing is just crazy," he said.

Closures keeping fishery sustainable

The most recent statistics for commercial barramundi catch in Queensland were recorded in 2023 at 788 tonnes, with more than half caught in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

Barramundi is already starting to come into fish shops in north Queensland. (ABC News: Brooke Tindall)

The Gulf of Carpentaria and east coast barramundi fisheries close from October and November respectively until February 1, to protect the species during its spawning period.

Pauline Jacob from the Queensland Department of Primary Industries (DPI) said the closures ensured a long-lasting supply.

"What we're trying to do is ensure that we're continually growing our fisheries to enable those fish to be at a sustainable level and remain on people's plates at the dinner table."

She said the barramundi closures were among the DPI's longest-standing measures in fishery management, introduced in 1981 after stock surveys and studies into barramundi spawning.

Nathan Rynn said his grandfather was a fisher when the closures were brought in.

"Ten years on from the closure, people like our grandfather said they felt worried at the time, but it did help the fishery."

title: Will $93 million be enough to improve school attendance at Roebourne?
text:
A remote school in Western Australia's Pilbara will be the state government's most expensive rebuild, despite having one of the lowest attendance rates in the state.

Roebourne, 1,550 kilometres north of Perth, has a district high school which teaches kindergarten to year 12.

In 2025, there were 141 students enrolled, but only one in four upper school students attended.

This averaged to 55 students across all year levels each day.

Attendance at Roebourne District High School is 60 per cent below the WA public school average. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

Cafe, performing arts upgrades

Fourteen-year-old Banjima and Ngarluma student Banjo Lockyer started year 10 at Roebourne District High School (RDHS) this week.

He estimated he attended school two or three days a week last year.

"There is more people outside of the school than inside it," he said.

Banjo Lockyer enjoys playing football when he goes to school. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

"I don't like going to school, to be honest, I don't like waking up early and just start doing work."

His mother, Roslyn Armstrong, said it was hard to encourage him to attend, and she would like to see more facilities at the school for students to learn a trade.

RDHS has one of the lowest attendance rates in the state with just one in four upper school students enrolled attending. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

The state government has contributed $73 million in upgrades, with works beginning in 2023, and last year, an extra $20 million was added by Woodside.

The upgrades are on track to be completed by September 2026.

The money has gone towards a cafe, a multi-purpose performing arts hall, science labs, music and drama classrooms, and a language centre.

Special audio systems in classrooms have also been installed for children who are hard of hearing, as well as showers and a laundry, plus yarning circles outside.

A 2021 public school review found the transient nature of RDHS and its low attendance rate to be its biggest obstacles.

Roebourne has a population of about 1,000 people and sits 30 minutes north of Karratha. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

Western versus cultural methods

Ngarluma and Yindjibarndi man Patrick Churnside said the funding was welcomed.

"It was good news, and a lot of the community was like, 'Yes, we're finally getting something for our community and the school,'" he said.

Patrick Churnside loved working on the school farm when he attended Roebourne District High School. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

But Mr Churnside said in First Nations culture, time was not a construct they abide by, which impacted access to education.

"In most indigenous or remote communities, time works differently compared to in the metropolitan or city or industrial regions," he said.

Patrick Churnside leads the Ngarlama traditional dancing group at an event in Dampier. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

"If there is time for education, it may not be in the set amount of time as the education system allows for an educator working clocked hours, which their system dictates or obligates them to.

"In a remote community, that's not the instance."

Low attendance, high support needs

Roebourne's average high school attendance was 28 per cent in 2025, well below the 81 per cent average for WA.

While for primary school students, the average attendance was 50 per cent, compared with the WA state average attendance of 89 per cent.

Demountables at Roebourne District High School placed over a basketball court. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

The majority of students at Roebourne District High School identify as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander.

The Department of Education website shows remote schools in the Kimberley and Goldfields have similar if not worse attendance levels.

NAPLAN testing undertaken at the school in 2025 showed between 71 per cent and 100 per cent of students needed additional support, with no students exceeding expectations.

The state government and Woodside have teamed up to deliver $93 million in upgrades to the school, which are set to be complete by the end of 2026. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

A non-Western approach to engagement

Roebourne-based charity Yaandina operate youth services in the town and have overhauled its systems after more Western-style ways of engagement failed to breakthrough.

"We tend to be more creative about it, and make it more focused on where the child feels safe or comfortable," chief executive officer Emma Dumbrell said.

Yaandina has a youth drop-in centre next to the school that offers programs and services such as dental visits and health care for kids aged five to 18. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

"[It] might mean taking them out fishing, just taking them for a drive and having a yarn."

Ms Dumbrell said the current youth alcohol and other drug counsellor now had a full caseload with none of the appointments being traditional one-on-one counselling.

Emma Dumbrell has worked in Roebourne for over a decade at Yaandina. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

Education Minister Sabine Winton said the school planned to combat low attendance with a new outreach engagement program for "chronically disengaged students" and would take part in the "connected communities" trial.

"This significant redevelopment will provide a culturally appropriate environment, with the aim of boosting student enrolment through to senior secondary years," she said.

Press releases and ribbon cutting

Nationals upper house member Julie Freeman, who has an office in Karratha, said the government cannot take a "build it and they will come" approach to education.

"I think the Cook Labor government has fallen into a real habit of funding things that they can cut ribbons on and have nice photo opportunities in front of," she said.

Landscaping at the newly updated Roebourne District High School features a large welcoming circle and yarning circles. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

"If only one in four children are actually turning up, then all the beautiful buildings in the world are not going to make a scrap of difference."

Meanwhile, in 2024, Esperance Senior High School topped the list of most building defects of any public school in WA.

While a vision for upgrades was completed in 2000, funding from the state governments has never been allocated.

title: 'I want to move forward': What happens to women after leaving prison?
text:
Loading...

Creative prison programs are celebrated for their ability to heal and transform incarcerated people.

But are they enough to break the cycle?

This story includes conversations about abuse, trauma and drug use, which could be triggering for some readers.

It's a sunny day and members of the Adelaide Symphony Orchestra (ASO) are dressed in the requisite head-to-toe black, fiddling with their instruments and looking over their sheet music as they prepare to perform.

Loading...

The gathered crowd isn't really there to see them — eight women with ukuleles who follow them on stage are the stars of the show.

These women also happen to be incarcerated in the Adelaide Women's Prison (AWP).

"All the songs you'll hear today were penned inside these walls," declares their mentor, Barkindji woman and singer-songwriter Nancy Bates.

"Through the laughter and the tears, we have dived deeply, searching for melodies and words, making light in the darkness of prison."

The audience comprises corrections staff, inmates and their loved ones.

Some of them are openly weeping.

Audience members laughed and cried throughout the performance. ( )

Along with AWP inmates and staff, the Songbirds' (the name given to the program's participants) family members were invited to attend the concert. ( )

As the sound of the orchestra swells behind them, the first woman begins singing.

Loading...

This performance is believed to be the biggest ever held in an Australian jail.

It's the culmination of the Songbirds music program, which saw 12 inmates turn some of their darkest experiences into music under Bates's direction.

It's also the subject of the award-winning Songs Inside documentary — written, directed and produced by Shalom Almond.

The project is more than just a film for Almond, who has worked with fellow producers Katrina Lucas and Lauren Drewery to challenge negative perceptions of incarcerated women and advocate for systemic change.

Since Songs Inside's 2024 debut, they have screened the film more than 60 times in communities and prisons across Australia. A few Songbirds (the name given to the program's participants) are selected out of a group of five to speak at each event.

Erin and Fabiann, who were both released from jail during or shortly after the program, are two of them.

Fabiann was one of eight Songbirds (out of the original 12 that started the program) who performed with the ASO. ( )

While Erin left the Songbirds music program early because she was released from prison, she's still involved with the Songs Inside project. ( )

In many ways, the experience has changed their lives.

Over a four-and-a-half-month period in 2023, the pair gathered with their fellow Songbirds at least twice a week in the depths of AWP's medium-security unit.

For two hours, prison life faded as Bates taught them how to read sheet music and play chords on their ukuleles, before they practised the songs they'd written about love and their fears and pain.

A correctional officer would watch over them along with Almond, who was joined by a second camera person.

Loading...

"If you look at the women who have been part of this journey from the premiere to now, the growth and self-discovery we've all experienced speaks volumes," says Erin.

"We've reconnected with ourselves, rediscovered our strengths and embraced our potential."

Fabiann feels like Songs Inside has shone a light on the reasons "people aren't getting any better, what is happening in jail [and] what people are coming out to" — from addiction, to trauma, to unemployment and housing insecurity.

But neither the music program, the film about it, a subsequent advocacy project, nor support from the Songs Inside team, could entirely shield the participants from the reality of re-entering the outside world.

About two years on from their release from AWP, Erin and Fabiann are still trying to rebuild their lives. The experts say this is a common reality.

Things had been going well for Fabiann in the program, but when she left prison in October 2023, she felt alone.

Loading...

"When I was incarcerated, I lost everything," she says. "My whole life was put out on the side of the road and I didn't have any connections with my family."

"I got out with nothing but the clothes on my back."

The reality of life beyond prison makes her feel something akin to guilt when she tells inmates at screenings that they too can turn their lives around.

The challenges weren't unexpected for Almond, who stayed in contact with Fabiann beyond prison, driving her five hours back to her hometown and helping her set up a life outside AWP.

Fabiann is now living in her own house, and has been working a part-time job alongside studying to become a social worker, while also touring the country for Songs Inside screenings. She doesn't think she would be where she is today without the support of the team behind the program.

Aerial view of Adelaide Women's Prison in Songs Inside. ( )

"The fact they can release people out in the street to nothing and then wonder why they're back there in a week is beyond me … what chance did they have?"

Erin's mid-program exit from AWP — with a sleeping bag in lieu of a place to live — was different to Fabiann's in that it was caught on camera.

Bates had made a commitment to continue the music program with Erin post-release, and Almond filmed what was meant to be their second meet-up.

Struggling with homelessness, Erin didn't appear that day, leading to one of the film's most searing moments.

"It was probably a big call to expect her to arrive today and step back into the program with me," Bates reflects to camera.

Erin describes life since her release from AWP as a "constant battle" she "wasn't fully prepared for".

Loading...

"I'd love to see more programs like [Songbirds] in prisons," she says. "But I think it's just as important to have more support for when people get out.

"That's when it really hits you — trying to rebuild from nothing, trying to find your place again. Having things like housing, work opportunities, mental health support … those things matter.

"If even a fraction of the money spent on locking someone up for a year went instead into real rehabilitation and proper transition support, that revolving door wouldn’t be spinning the way it does."

A few weeks after her release from prison, Erin found temporary housing with Almond's help and made her way back to the group.

But having only secured a transitional housing contract, she faced the very real possibility of ending up right where she started.

"I want to move forward. I want the last two years of effort to mean something. I want a chance to live outside the cycle — not just survive, but actually build a life," Erin says.

" And yet, without secure housing it feels like the system is stacked against me. "

Songs Inside is Almond's second documentary in the prison space.

It came after 2017's Prisoners and Pups, which drove her to create a film that offered a deeper look at the issues incarcerated women face both inside and coming back out into the community.

Prisoners and Pups was also filmed inside AWP, in 2015, and followed inmates as they trained former racing greyhounds for adoption. ( )

A little over a year on from its release, Almond thinks Songs Inside's ability to shine a light on the struggles of incarcerated women without "ramming them down" audiences' throats is one of its greatest strengths.

But she's realistic about the limitations.

Almond says she hopes the "kinds of eyeballs we've been able to get in front of the film ... are going to be able to make real change". ( )

Almond, right, filming Bates, left, appears in Songs Inside only as a disembodied voice. ( )

"Nancy [Bates] has this incredibly special way of engaging the women, drawing them into her world and creating an emotionally safe space for them to be able to open up," Almond says.

" Music programs 100 per cent have their place in prison, but the issues around addiction, trauma, lack of housing, all the very complex challenges women face when they get out ... music is definitely not strong enough to overcome any of that. "

Songs Inside was released at a time when the number of adult women incarcerated in Australia had increased by almost a third over the preceding decade.

The number of women being sent to prison continues to rise, with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women disproportionately represented in the prison system.

Then there are the reoffending (recidivism) rates.

In Australia, 53.6 per cent of adults released from prison return to corrective services with a new correctional sanction (prison sentence or a community corrections order) within two years. In South Australia, that figure is 36.8 per cent.

A spokesperson for SA's Department for Correctional Services said the state has a range of programs that provide "community-based accommodation and reintegration support", which provide "clear pathways to stability" and deliver lower recidivism.

Dr Mindy Sotiri, executive director of the Justice Reform Initiative (JRI), says films like Songs Inside help both "people inside by giving a voice to stories that are often hidden" as well as those of us outside, "who haven't really understood" why people end up there.

But she also thinks there's a tension between telling stories such as Erin and Fabiann's and deepening public understanding.

Stream Songs Inside on ABC iview A group of incarcerated women sign up for a unique songwriting program, which for some opens up deep scars and for others proves to be life-changing.

"Any public storytelling that any of us do then exists forever, and ultimately the power needs to be held by the people who have the stories to tell," she considers.

Fabiann and Erin say they have no regrets about sharing their stories for the world to see.

A 2017 documentary made about Bell Shakespeare's Youth Justice Program took a different approach to sharing the stories of its participants.

The film, Kings of Baxter, followed a group of juvenile inmates as they worked together over 12 weeks to stage Macbeth.

Joanna Erskine, who oversees the initiative, says the team knew very little identifying information about the young people they worked with. And in the film, none of the participants' faces were shown in their entirety to maintain their anonymity.

The program sees the young people use Shakespeare's works as a tool for critical and creative thinking that can help them explore their experiences without directly talking about themselves.

"A couple of weeks ago … one of the young women was picking up on the regret Macbeth has for his actions and she said, 'That's how I feel about being here'. That wasn't something we asked her to do," Erskine says.

Barbed wire fence at Adelaide Women's Prison in Songs Inside. ( )

"Because of Shakespeare's perceived difficulty, once they get it, it unlocks something in them and they're like: 'What else can I do?'"

Since her team knows little more than the first names of the young people they work with, Erskine says they are unable to track reoffending rates.

"But what we are able to measure is the skills developed," she says.

"We know, for example, they are more confident doing a job interview … or they carry themselves in a different way because they feel pride in what they've achieved."

Dr Sotiri says she isn't aware of any data on reoffending rates for people who have taken part in creative prison programs in Australia.

"That's not a thing that's commonly measured in Australia," she explains.

"But there's quite a lot of research that says if you create an identity and social connections outside of the justice system, you are much less likely to go back to prison."

And yet, Flinders University criminology lecturer Jeremy Ryder says creative prison programs are not only rare, but "really vulnerable to being cancelled".

Loading...

"Often in prison, the courses that you do are focused on criminogenic risks and needs like alcohol and drugs, managing your emotions and propensity for violence."

While Dr Ryder thinks these programs have their place, he says they can reinforce the idea that inmates are "defective" human beings.

Creative programs, on the other hand, "are grounded in building up confidence, strength, reintegrating that person into a group and giving them skills".

Combined with other supports, he says they allow incarcerated people to "create an identity that overpowers their former identities … providing a pathway from prisoner back to citizen".

However everyone, from the Songbirds to the experts, are in agreement: creative programs can only do so much.

"Someone in prison might have got an enormous amount from participation in a creative program, but the emptiness of what is available for people when they're released can feel even more shocking in a way," Dr Sotiri continues.

"And that's a failure of a number of systems."

To reduce reoffending rates, Dr Sotiri says at-risk people need to be better supported in the community to avoid incarceration, and those who do end up in prison, need the underlying reasons addressed.

Dr Ryder puts it bluntly.

Ukulele strumming in Songs Inside. ( )

"People want the 'art saved' [all] story, and it can happen, but it's got to happen in conjunction with other things," he says.

"A ukulele can only get you so far when you don't have a job, and insecure housing."

The Songbirds music program is expected to return to AWP this year, and Almond wants to resume screening Songs Inside in schools, "as an educational tool and as a deterrent".

Erin knows the Songbirds and the Songs Inside team don't have the power to make the changes they'd like to see on their own.

"If it was as simple as five women standing on stage sharing their stories to make systemic change, it would have been done by now," she says.

"But hopefully we can open the ... minds of those that can."

For now, Erin and Fabiann hope to continue using their lived experience to help others.

The former is studying for a certificate in women's advocacy, while the latter is due to complete her social work studies early this year, and hopes to set up a peer support program for inmates.

Loading...

"They feel more comfortable speaking to us than they do counsellors or other people," Fabiann says.

"To sit across from them and know exactly the pain they're sitting in and empower them to believe that coming back is possible, because the person sitting across from them has done it, it's living proof that with the right consistency, community and supports, they can do it too."

Watch the Songs Inside documentary free on ABC iview.

Victims of crime may be linked to some of the article's participants. This story does not seek to negate the experience of victims, nor condone criminal activity.

title: Award-winning fish and chip shop feels the pinch after WA fishing bans
text:
A two-time winner of Australia's Best Takeaway Fish and Chips says it has been forced to increase prices considerably following Western Australia's demersal fishing reforms.

Major changes to the state's fishing rules came into force on January 1, closing commercial fishing on the west coast.

Hooked on Middleton owner Shane Vale said the flow-on impact was already being felt further afield in Albany, 400 kilometres south of Perth.

"We're suffering and we're actually not even in the area where there is any bans at the moment," he said.

Fish and Chips from Hooked on Middleton in Albany. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Rising prices and limited availability

Fishers along WA's south coast have been securing higher prices for their catch in Perth, due to regular supplies from the north being thin on the ground.

"The fishermen have told us that if you want to keep buying the fish, we have to match the price that they can get in Perth or get close to it," Mr Vale said.

He has had to raise his menu prices to accommodate the cost, with a serve of fried or grilled nannygai rising from $31 to $40.

"Since I have put the price of our nannygai and our pink snapper up by 30 per cent, we have definitely sold, well, probably 50 per cent less of our full serves," he said.

Fresh Nannygai is a popular fish on the Hooked on Middleton menu. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Additionally, availability of Spanish mackerel, which Mr Vale sources from WA's northern fisheries, has diminished.

"I have not been able to buy that this week and that's the first time in 20 years," he said.

"So I presume that the demand for that in Perth has skyrocketed."

Adapting menus

While the 50 per cent catch reduction was "officially" in place from January 1 this year, its practical implication is yet to be fully worked out.

A Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development spokesperson said the state government was still considering how the reduction will be implemented.

WA fisheries minister defends demersal fish ban A "judgement call" about a permanent commercial fishing ban for demersal species went further than the advice handed to her, WA's Fisheries Minister Jackie Jarvis says.

Mr Vale is now examining options for premium fish dishes that would absorb the elevated costs.

"I'm thinking of many other ways to be able to use less fish in smaller portions that people can still be happy with," he said.

He expected to adjust his menu further as the impact of the catch reduction became clearer.

"I would hope that we are still going to get some fish from Perth," he said.

"I do need a premium fish for that customer base that we do have … so I think it's a waiting game."

Hooked on Middleton has twice been named Australia’s best takeaway fish and chip shop. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Uncertainty for the south coast

Commercial fishers said they had been told the reduction would be implemented as an annual seasonal line and trap fishery closure between April and September.

Fishing of demersals like Albany Nannygai will be affected when commercial catch reductions come in for the South Coast. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Albany fisher Drew Mayfield said despite the recent higher prices, he still had significant concern for the future.

"Everyone's asking for fish and you just can't supply it," he said.

"The weather's not always good down here, so we only catch what we catch for the year and that doesn't fluctuate too much."

Demersal fishing reforms introduced in Western Australia. (Supplied: DPIRD)

Previously, Mr Mayfield said he sold all his catch to local buyers.

"So now it's gone a lot further, it's all going to Perth because of the ban that we're supposed to be getting," he said.

" You just have to chase the better dollars for the uncertainty of when you actually will and won't be able to fish. "

Drew Mayfield is bracing for the commercial catch to be reduced. (Supplied)

Mr Mayfield said it had been challenging to raise prices on long-term local customers.

"It's pretty hard because the guys I do sell to I know personally, I've been to their 50 or 60th birthdays and things like that," he said.

"They know it has to happen, it's still not as much as what we're getting in Perth for the fish so still trying to take it easy on them, but it's obviously going to make their business struggle as well."

title: Piastri defends McLaren, expects 'fair shot' at F1 title
text:
Oscar Piastri insists the painful ending to his F1 title bid last season has only strengthened his resolve to be the "nice person" who brings the Formula 1 world drivers' crown back to Australia.

Piastri led the F1 drivers' championship for the majority of last season, but a form slump in the final third of the season meant the Australian finished third behind champion and teammate, Lando Norris and Red Bull's Max Verstappen.

Piastri was also on the wrong end of a few controversial moments for the McLaren team, but the Melbourne-born racer was adamant he had been given a "fair shot" by the UK-based team.

Piastri came so close, but these minor moments let the F1 title slip away Oscar Piastri missed out on winning the Formula 1 drivers world championship by just 13 points to his teammate Lando Norris, the culmination of multiple small moments throughout the season that cost him dearly.

Ahead of the 2026 season, Piastri said he expected the same even-handed approach as he reflected on his 2025 near-miss by revealing his pride in how he had handled the late-season drama.

As the pair faced the media at McLaren's HQ in Woking, before a season of sweeping changes to F1's cars and technical regulations, Piastri sounded buoyed and refreshed by the support he had received on his return to Australia.

"It was nice to go back and spend some time with my family and just take a bit of a step away from F1 and racing," the 24-year-old said.

"Going back home this Christmas was a bit different to the previous summers; definitely a few more people knew who I was.

"And just the support I had from being in the title fight and the amount of comments I got just about the way I go about things was honestly nice to hear.

"Obviously, I'm not here just to be known as just a 'nice person' or someone that goes about things in a way that people think is good. I'm here to try and become an F1 world champion — but I'm very proud of the way I've gone about things.

"There's a lot of lessons from last year and, yes, the ending was a bit painful, but you can treat that in one of two ways.

"Either you can let it bring you down or let it give you more confidence and motivation for the future — and with such a different rule-set this year, that's been a very good avenue to channel any motivation I gained over the off-season."

Piastri had returned home post-season amid much indignation about how he had seemingly been the one to suffer from most of the contentious calls McLaren made when trying to implement the team's much-trumpeted Papaya Rules, which preach driver equality amid a team-first environment.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

When asked by AAP whether he felt he had had a raw deal, the driver played the team man as usual.

"I think I got a fair shot last year, and I'm expecting that to stay exactly the same," Piastri said.

"That's definitely not to say that certain things could have been done better last year — I think that was probably clear for everyone watching — but I think, for me, at no point were there any bad intentions, or any times I questioned the intentions.

"Things could have been done better, handled differently, but that's part of elite sport and F1. You're never going to get every decision right or make every single person happy.

"So I think I got a fair shot last year, and we're working on how we can improve things and make sure that we try and become stronger."

After testing the new smaller, nippier McLaren last week at the start of F1's brave new world in Barcelona, Piastri reported it was "quite different to last year" but "not as alien as we might have feared".

After further testing sessions in Bahrain later this month, Piastri's eyes are set firmly on his home season-opener in Melbourne in March, where last year he skidded off when in line for a podium finish.

"Hopefully, it goes a bit better than last year, but it's going to be such an unknown for everybody that at this point, I'm just trying to maximise the time I've got in Bahrain testing and hit the ground running," he said.

"But for me, after the amount of support I gained over the last 12 months, especially in Australia, it's going to be nice to be back racing at home."

AAP

title: Dozens of skiers rescued at New York mountain
text:
Nearly 70 people have been rescued from gondola cabins at a New York ski mountain after a mechanical problem forced a shutdown of the lift system.

The skiers were stranded for hours, with some trapped up to 21 metres in the air, authorities said.

Staff at Gore Mountain in North Creek, north of Albany, climbed lift poles and used rope and body harnesses to lower people to the ground.

The operation took nearly 5 hours. No one was injured.

About 67 skiers in 20 gondola cabins were helped back down to the ground.

The tower wheel assembly of the gondola lift moved out of alignment and triggered a safety sensor. (AP: Mike Groll)

Skier: 'It was sobering'

There was some anxiety among those trapped, and worries about having to use the bathroom, people on the mountain said.

Although the temperatures were below freezing, the cabins remained warm as the doors were closed and the sun was shining, they said.

"It was sobering and something that I'll probably carry with me for the rest of my life," one skier said.

Spanish chairlift accident injures dozens A chairlift collapses at a winter resort in the Pyrenees mountains in the north of Spain, injuring dozens and leaving skiers stranded.

"You think nothing of getting on a lift or getting on a gondola, and now you're going to think twice.

"You're going to make sure you go to the bathroom and maybe have a power bar with you and make sure you're prepared, just like if you were going into the woods on a hike."

He said the rescues went very smoothly, and he complimented the professionalism of the rangers and ski area staff.

The New York State Olympic Regional Development Authority, which operates Gore Mountain, said the tower wheel assembly of the gondola lift moved out of alignment, triggered a safety sensor and the lift was stopped immediately.

"Our trained mountain operations team carried out the evacuation, and guests were supported throughout the process," the authority said in a statement.

"Safety remains our top priority, and our teams are fully trained and experienced in managing situations like this."

Park rangers and Gore Mountain ski patrol had trained together for gondola evacuations in November, climbing lift towers and traversing along cables to reach the gondolas, just as they did on Wednesday, officials said.

The gondola lift reopened on Thursday, local time.

AP

title: How magnetic fields, psychedelics and ketamine are helping treat the brain
text:
Jim Lagopoulos handles extraordinarily complex mental health cases every day, but he has a simple way to explain why his team's approach differs from many others.

"Psychiatry is generally done on subjective measures: how a patient is feeling, their mood, their behaviours," Dr Lagopoulos said.

"The work we do here is based on objective measures."

The neurophysiologist is the chief executive and founder of Thompson Brain and Mind Healthcare, a not-for-profit based on Queensland's Sunshine Coast that uses novel therapies to treat patients.

Brain scans are used during TMS therapy to deliver targeted magnetic pulses. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

It begins with an MRI of the brain.

"If someone breaks their bone and you don't send them off for an X-ray, what are the chances of us being able to treat that effectively? The brain is exactly the same," Dr Lagopoulos said.

" We can now see changes in brain function and brain metabolism, and we can use that information, and we treat that information — this is very new. "

Treatments used at the centre include transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and ketamine therapy.

It is also the only Queensland site selected for phase three of a global trial, sponsored by Cybin IRL Ltd, testing the effectiveness of psilocybin to treat major depressive disorders.

Psilocybin is the active ingredient in magic mushrooms and was approved for use, along with MDMA, by Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration in 2023.

Dr Lagopoulos says the centre's novel treatments come off the back of more than 20 years of research. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

'I'm a newborn person'

In just two years, the Maroochydore clinic has grown from three staff members to 40, including doctors, psychologists and dieticians.

Jonny Doughty is among the patients.

The musician and songwriter said when he first walked into the clinic in early 2025, he was a broken man.

Dr Lagopoulos speaking with Jonny Doughty at the clinic, which takes patients through referrals. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

He had suffered decades of mental and physical trauma after enduring horrific sexual abuse as a child.

Ketamine treatment becomes cheaper for patients A new nasal spray that uses a form of ketamine to treat stubborn depression will be added to the PBS, making treatment cheaper for thousands of Australians.

"My life has been a series of rolling, extremely traumatic events," he said.

"I've tried every medication under the sun as well. I was pretty much at the end of my rope."

His treating physician recommended ketamine therapy, which is being prescribed for patients who have not found success with standard antidepressants, with the medication added to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) in May last year.

"For the first time in my entire life, I can function cognitively and emotionally. The world looks, smells and feels different," Mr Doughty said.

He said the treatment had allowed him to deal with life's challenges in a positive way.

"I don't just crawl up into a ball, I don't wake up screaming anymore. My nightmares have gone. My hands no longer shake. I sleep," he said.

" After the second treatment of the ketamine, I slept, for the first time in decades, the entire night. It's like I'm a newborn person. "

Jonny Doughty hopes more people can gain access to ketamine therapy, which he says has changed his life. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

Long battle with brain injury

Rosemary Cotterill also has high praise for Dr Lagopoulos and his team.

The sports scientist suffered a devastating brain injury after falling down a flight of stairs seven years ago.

"I tried everything I could do, but it was actually getting worse," she said.

"I was passing all the functional tests, but when Jim actually showed the scan results to me, and they're very comprehensive, they showed the degree of my brain injury and how much I've been suffering, so no wonder I was depressed."

Rosemary Cotterill says TMS therapy has been "life-changing" for her. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

She underwent an intense course of TMS therapy, which involves using magnetic fields to stimulate specific parts of the brain.

"The first thing I noticed was the reduction in pain. My mental acuity started picking up within the first week or so," she said.

Ms Cotterill said even her neurologist was impressed.

"My brain's looking good, really good. I'm just continually improving," she said.

" I cannot begin to describe what a difference it made to me. It was just life-changing. "

Rosemary Cotterill hugging Dr Lagopoulos, who she says has helped her feel optimistic about the future. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

'No doubt' therapies work — for the right patients

Clinical psychiatrist Colleen Loo, from the Black Dog Institute, said the use of MRI scans in combination with other treatments was an "emerging area".

The University of New South Wales professor will soon be working with University of Melbourne researchers on a randomised controlled trial to study the results of using an MRI approach to TMS therapy compared to TMS without a brain scan.

"To see if it does make a difference because nobody has actually demonstrated that comparison ... but TMS is generally an effective and good treatment," Professor Loo said.

She said there was also no doubt that ketamine therapy worked — but not for everyone.

"It depends on the nature of the problem you have, the type of depression," the professor said.

"Some people will not benefit at all. For other people, it will be like a complete cure.

"There does need to be very careful medical supervision and monitoring — without that, it can have serious risks."

She said the real challenge was making the therapies accessible and affordable, with ketamine treatment and monitoring costs not covered by Medicare.

High hopes for hospital

Peak advocacy group Mental Health Australia estimates about half a million people nationwide are missing out on essential psychosocial support.

Chief executive Carolyn Nikoloski said there was a need for "real change" and called for a greater funding commitment ahead of this month's meeting of the country's health and mental health ministers.

"We need stronger investment in community settings so people can access the right care, in the right place, at the right time," Ms Nikoloski said.

An artist's impression of the facility planned for Birtinya. (Supplied: Thompson Brain & Mind Healthcare)

Dr Lagopolous said his group hoped to meet growing demand for services on the Sunshine Coast through a new hospital dedicated to treating and researching mental health conditions.

The eight-storey facility will be built at a site at Birtinya, but since the plans were first revealed, construction costs have risen from $77 million to an estimated $100 million.

Sunshine Coast philanthropists Roy and Nola Thompson have donated more than $50 million towards the hospital project. (Supplied: University of the Sunshine Coast)

The CEO said that while most of the funding had been secured, he was working with the state and federal governments to secure the remainder.

"It's an innovation precinct, which basically means there will be doctors working with patients, researchers working with brains. It's an Australian first," he said.

"Because we don't nicely nest into health or education, trying to identify the remaining sums of money we need to start the building is difficult — but I think we're close."

title: Judge criticises Abbott's 'misconceived' comments over harbour bridge protest
text:
The New South Wales chief justice has criticised Tony Abbott's "misconceived" comments on a judge's decision to approve a pro-Palestinian march on the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

The former prime minister said it should not be for judges to decide when a political protest was justified, in a social media post following Justice Belinda Rigg's ruling last August.

In a speech to the legal profession on Thursday night, Chief Justice Andrew Bell said Mr Abbott's remarks were regrettable.

The chief justice said Justice Rigg's decision was not about whether a political protest was justified, as would have been clear "to anyone who took the time to read it".

"This comment was, with respect, misconceived," Chief Justice Bell said.

In the post, Mr Abbott said the decision to close the harbour bridge to facilitate the protest was political.

"[It] should be made by elected and accountable ministers — [sic] who as it happens, think the march should not go ahead," his post continued.

"We are on a slippery slope when unelected judges start making political judgments."

Tony Abbott voiced his concerns on the topic via a social media post. (ABC News: Andy Kennedy)

Judge says decision not political

Chief Justice Bell said Justice Rigg did not make the decision to close the bridge as authorities had already made that call, adding the legislature expressly gave the court responsibility for the decision.

"Her Honour's decision was not a 'political' judgement but involved the careful weighing of the common law and constitutionally protected right to free speech and public assembly with considerations such as public safety," the chief justice said.

He said social cohesion was not enhanced when judicial decisions were attacked in a way that betrayed an "ignorance" of the law and the judge's reasoning.

Chief Justice Bell said such attacks were a form of misinformation that undermined trust in the judiciary and the rule of law.

"They corrosively suggest or imply that the community cannot have confidence the judiciary is independent and that judges are not conscientiously and in good faith endeavouring to do their jobs consistent with their judicial oaths," the chief justice said.

" That is regrettable to say the least. Some might call it irresponsible. "

Chief Justice Bell says the former prime minister's comments are "misconceived". (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

The chief justice pointed out he presided over a Court of Appeal decision later in the year to prevent a protest at the Sydney Opera House, which he said involved a "similar weighing exercise and risk assessment".

Mr Abbott told the ABC he stood by his comment.
